Fig. 1 Model of a nanosized particle formed via the interaction of (a) M(acac)2‒AlEt3 and (b) M(acac)2‒ LiAlH4 (where M=Co, Ni, or Pd) under the conditions of hydrogenation catalysis [11,18]. Fig 1 Fig. 2 Hydrogenation of styrene in the presence of a catalytic system based on (a) Ni(acac)2 + 5AlEt3 modified with triethylamine, (b) Ni(acac)2 + 5AlEt3 modified with tributylamine: СNi = 5.6 mmol/L, [substrate]/Ni = 87, solvent – benzene-octane (V benzen e/Voctane = 15/2), portion of styrene = 1 ml of styrene, [amine]/[AlEt3]=0.5, solvent volume = 17 ml; Т = 30 °С, РH2 =2 atm. The arrow indicates the place where an aliquot of the reaction solution (12 ml) was taken. Fig 2 Fig. 3 (a) Dark-field TEM image and diffraction pattern (inset) and (b) X-ray microanalysis results for the system Ni(acac)2–5AlEt3 modified with NEt3 (amine/AlEt3 = 0.5) after hydrogenation of three portions of styrene (3 ml styrene). СNi = 5.6 mmol/L, [substrate]/Ni = 87 (1 ml St), solvent – benzene-octane (V benzene /Voctane = 15/2), [amine]/[AlEt3]=1.0, solvent volume = 17 ml. Fig 3 Fig. 4 1Н NMR spectra of NEt3−AlEt3 at the ratio NEt3/AlEt3 = 1: solvent – toluene–d8, [Al] = 0.1 mol/L. Fig 4 Fig. 5 13C NMR spectra of NEt3−AlEt3 at the ratio NEt3/AlEt3 = 1: solvent – toluene –d8, [Al] = 0.1 mol/L. Fig 5 Fig. 6 27Al NMR spectra of NEt3−AlEt3 at the ratio of NEt3/AlEt3 = 1: solvent – toluene –d8, [Al] = 0.1 mol/L. Fig 6 Fig. 7 1Н NMR spectra of Ni(acac)2 – 5AlEt3, where * – AlEt3, Ас – AlEt2(acac): solvent – toluene–d8, [Al] = 0.1 mol/L. The paper reports on a possible modification of the multicomponent catalytic system based on Ni(acac)2 and AlEt3 by different amines. It is shown that, depending on the nature of the amine, the performance of the modified Ni(acac)2–AlEt3 system is limited only to the size of the reaction vessel. Using various physical-chemical methods, it is found that during the formation of a catalytically active system, the NR3→AlEt3 adducts are produced. The latter, unlike AlEt3 excess, are not able of poisoning the nickel-containing catalytically active centers. The model of the formation of a catalytically active site in the presence of an amine is proposed. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Hydrogenation Multicomponent nickel catalytic systems Amine Activation Adduct Data availability Data will be made available on request. Introduction It is known that about 25% of all chemical processes or approximately 8% of the world's gross domestic product fall on catalytic hydrogenation [1]. Since hydrogenation is the most popular reaction employed for the production of chemicals, it commands the major attention of catalytic community. Currently, the most prospective hydrogenation catalysts are recognized to be nano-sized particles of transition metals formed on the basis of multicomponent systems [2]. Such catalysts possess high activity under mild conditions and good selectivity towards products. Also, they allow selectivity of the process to be controlled via the modification with various additives. Unfortunately, many structural effects of the multicomponent systems on their catalytic properties cannot be unambiguously rationalized due to the lack of reliable experimental data on the role of each component of the system in the formation of active catalytic particles and their composition [2–6]. For example, the issue of the structure of catalytically active site still remains obscure, which makes it difficult or even impossible to predict the catalytic properties of new systems. First of all, this is due to the multicomponent nature of such systems, high sensitivity to impurities presented in the reaction mixture, process conditions both at the stage of catalyst formation and during the catalysis, as well as reactions that can occur in multicomponent catalytic systems [3,7]. These are redox reactions affording new complexes of transition metals in various oxidation states, and acid-base process. Importantly, depending on the system structure, the same compounds should be considered as acids or as Lewis bases. For example, aluminum alkyl compounds, typical Lewis acids, upon contact with cobalt and nickel complexes in lower oxidation states, are bases, while Co(0) and Ni(0) complexes represent Lewis acids [8]. Previously, it was shown [9–18] that catalytic systems based on acetylacetonate complexes of cobalt, nickel or palladium in combination with AlEt3 or LiAlH4 and their alkoxy derivatives in solvents of an “achievable” degree of purity (water content is no more than 2 mmol/L) represent nanoparticles consisting of a metal core (0.7–5.0 nm) stabilized by a ligand shell. The latter are aluminum acetylacetonate compounds and AlEt3 in the case, when it was used as a cocatalyst (Fig. 1 (a)). In LiAlH4-derived systems, the ligand shell comprises Li(acac), as well as AlH4 – and AlH6 3– anions (Fig. 1(b)). It is a common knowledge that electrostatic binding contributes heavily to the formation of such structures [19]. On the other hand, it is a matter of general experience that metal nanoparticles of lower size possess higher electron deficiency [20], and hence the Lewis acidity. Therefore, it cannot be ruled out that a part of aluminum is bound via acid–base interaction, and the strength of Lewis bases adsorption (for example, [AlH4]– - anions) on electron-deficient metal particles should enhance with growth of these particles dispersity [21]. It has been suggested that the aluminum-containing fragments on the surface of nanoparticles act as a catalytic poison [11,18]. On this premise, a new approach to the synthesis of multicomponent catalysts based on nickel, palladium or cobalt acetylacetonates has been developed. According to this approach, proton-donating compounds are employed as activators to remove catalytic poisons from the surface of transition metal nanoparticles that are inert in the hydrogenation [11,15,17,18]. Also, novel methods for the synthesis of highly efficient metal multicomponent catalysts, derived from M(acac)2 –Red (M=Ni, Co, Pd; Red=AlEt3, LiAlH4), for the hydrogenation of alkenes, alkynes, carbonyl and nitro compounds [9-11,14,15,18,22] as well as arenes [18,23,24] were elaborated. In continuation of our studies on further development of the above concept and the elaboration of new highly active and productive catalysts for the hydrogenation of alkene, here we report on the application of amines as modifiers of multicomponent Ni(acac)2‒AlEt3-based systems. It should be noted that the modification of multicomponent catalytic systems for the oligo- and/or polymerization of olefins with Lewis bases [25–27] is a common strategy to control their activity and stereoselectivity. Meanwhile, the data on the use of Lewis bases as modifiers of multicomponent catalytic hydrogenation systems are lacking in the literature. Experimental The methods for purification and drying of gasses, solvents, substrates, amines, Ni(acac)2 and AlEt3, hydrogenation protocols and EPR experiments were described in detail in [11,15,23,28,29] and Supplementary Material (SM). Results and discussion Hydrogenation experiments The reactions of sublimated Ni(acac)2 with AlEt3 in an inert atmosphere and under conditions of hydrogenation catalysis were previously discussed in detail in [11,15,16]. Therefore, it should be briefly mentioned here that after the mixing of Ni(acac)2 and AlEt3 (Al/Ni=5–10) in a hydrogen atmosphere, a dark-brown homogeneous solution is formed (TEM and EPR data), which does not exert catalytic activity in the styrene hydrogenation. After the introduction of a modifier (amine) into the reaction solution, the catalytic activity appears and grows, and the quantitative parameters (TOF and TON. TOF and TON calculation methodology is presented in the SM) of the catalytic system, under other equal conditions, depend on the modifier nature (Table 1 ). It should be noted that the Al/Ni=5 ratio was chosen as a model ratio based on the previously obtained experimental data [18]. Table 2 shows the quantitative parameters of the most active catalytic systems formed in the presence of several aliphatic amines. The dependence of TOF and TON on the [amine]/[AlEt3] ratio is of extreme character, reaching maximum values for almost all studied amines at [amine]/[AlEt3]=0.25÷0.5. Probably, this fact can be explained as follows: at [amine]/[AlEt3]< 0.25÷0.5, the modifier concentration in the system is insufficient to form the optimal number of active sites. On the other hand, when [amine]/[AlEt3]>0.5, the amine competes for active sites, which reduces the catalytic activity of the system. The highest catalytic activity at the ratio of [amine]/[AlEt3]=0.5 was achieved, when tributylamine (∼88.5 min−1) and triethylamine (∼60.0 min−1), as well as at [amine]/[AlEt3]=0.25 when diethylamine (∼84.5 min−1) were used as modifiers. In all three cases, TON was ≥ 3400 (see Table 2). It should be emphasized that the value of TON≥3400 is indicated conditionally, since the technical capabilities of the “duck” type of the reaction vessel did not allow hydrogenation of more than 39 ml of styrene. If after hydrogenation of the 39th ml of styrene (or at any other hydrogenation stage), reaction solution aliquot (10–12 ml) was removed from the «duck» and hydrogenation was continued, the activity of the next styrene portions was much higher than that of the sample, which preceded the aliquot (Fig. 2 ). It is known that the amines possess the pronounced basic properties. The obtained experimental data (see Table 2) suggest that the quantitative parameters of TOF and TON can correlate with the basicity of the amine-modifier [30,31]. Physical-chemical methods of research The UV spectroscopic and volumetric study of the reaction between Ni(acac)2 and AlEt3 in a benzene was reported in [11,15]. Here, we should notice that the addition of an amine as a modifier to the already formed Ni(acac)2 – 5AlEt3 system does not lead to additional release of gaseous products or appearance of the extra absorption bands in the UV spectrum, regardless of the nature of the amine and amine/AlEt3 ratio. According to the data of EPR spectroscopy (temperature of liquid nitrogen), for the reaction solutions formed in the presence of all the studied amines, the signal of ferromagnetic resonance (FMR) is absent at g ∼ 2.2. In this case, if to record the EPR spectra at room temperature, then, depending on the nature of the modifier and the sampling time during the hydrogenation, a broadened low intense FMR signal appears in the spectrum. Probably, this signal is due to the effect of the spectrometer magnetic field. It was reported [32–34] that the absence of the FMR signal can be associated with the generation of very small (no more than 0.8 nm) nickel-containing particles that do not possess ferromagnetic properties. Fig. 3 shows a TEM microimage and electron diffraction pattern for the Ni(acac)2–AlEt3 system modified with NEt3. Obviously, the crystalline particles were not detected on the image. This fact is confirmed by the diffused diffraction pattern. It should be stressed that the technical capabilities of the electron microscope used (see Experimental) do not allow the particles smaller than 0.7 nm in diameter to be detected [11] Fig. 3a. Elemental microanalysis of the samples allows the content of the following main elements Ni, C, Al, and O to be determined (see Fig. 3b). The absence of N among these elements can be explained by the fact that during the preparation of the TEM sample, the adduct is destroyed and NEt3 molecule is removed from the sample surface in vacuum (see the description of the preparation of TEM samples in SM). According to the formula for calculation of atom numbers in a metal nanoparticle [35], the nickel-containing center formed in the systems under consideration should contain no more than 16 nickel atoms (taking into account that the particle has only nickel atoms). In addition, the same results were also obtained after hydrogenation of 20 portions of styrene, i.e., catalytically active species extremely resistant to aggregation were generated in the system. It is known that the interaction of AlEt3 with amines [36–38] furnishes stable (at room temperature), transparent, colorless liquid adducts, Et3Al∙amine, which, like amines, have Lewis basicity. However, it was also reported [39] that the reaction AlEt3 with NR3 can give compounds of the AlEt2(NR)2 type. On the other hand, as noted above, electron deficiency of metal nanoparticles increases with a decrease in their size [20,40-43]. Thus, it can be assumed that the acid-base interaction between the surface sites of small particles of the reduced metal and the Et3Al∙amine adduct can deliver highly stable systems under the conditions of styrene hydrogenation. The obtained values of TOF and TON can be explained by such high stability (Table 2), while the drop in catalytic activity is probably owing to a strong dilution of the reaction solution with the hydrogenation product and a decrease in the stirring intensity (since the free volume of the reaction vessel physically decreases). Indirectly, this assumption is confirmed by the fact that after removal of the reaction solution aliquot (and, consequently, increasing the free volume of the reaction vessel), hydrogenation TOF of the next portions of styrene sharply increases (Fig. 2). To explain all the experimental data presented in the work, additional in-depth studies are required. First of all, the reaction of AlEt3 and the products of its transformation with amines under the conditions of hydrogenation catalysis should be examined by the NMR technique (1Н, 13С, 15N, 27Al). In this line, it is no coincidence that NEt3 was chosen as a reference compound. Firstly, the system Ni(acac)2 – 5AlEt3 – 5NEt3 turned out to be one of the most active and productive among the described multicomponent catalytic systems [7,11,44,45]. Secondly, NEt3 is easy purified and stable upon storage [28]. Thirdly, its 1Н, 13С and 15N spectra are characteristic and rather simple [46–48]. The signal assignment of the components of the system Ni(acac)2 – 5AlEt3 – 5NEt3 system is given in Table 3 . After addition of the calculated amount of NEt3 to AlEt3 (NEt3/AlEt3 = 1), the 1Н NMR spectra (Fig. 4 ) shows the signals at 0.26 (q, CH2), 1.21 (t, CH3), 1.49 (t, CH3) and 2.77 (q, CH2) ppm, which are assigned to the Al-CH 2-CH3, NCH2 CH 3, Al-CH2 CH 3, and N CH 2-CH3 of the NEt3→AlEt3 adduct, respectively. The shifts of 1H NMR signals for both acceptor and donor groups with respect to the spectra of the initial compounds were previously described [49]. Similar changes are detected in the 13C NMR spectrum of the system NEt3→AlEt3 (Fig. 5 ). The broadening of the signal at 2.80 ppm is probably due to the effect of the aluminum quadrupole nucleus. A weak intense signal at 60.0 ppm is attributed to the –O–CH2– fragment of the alumoxano like compound. The latter is the presence of trace water in the reaction system and on the walls of the reaction vessel and NMR ampoule. In the 27Al NMR spectrum, a signal at 174 ppm (Fig. 6 ) corresponds to the NEt3→AlEt3, while in the 15N spectrum this adducts is characterized by the signal at −133 ppm. The signals from the initial NEt3 or AlEt3 are absent in the spectra. The width of the 27Al NMR signals of AlEt3 and NEt3→AlEt3 adduct is due to the quadrupole expansion [54,55]. In addition, the 2D NOESY spectrum has been recorded for the system NEt3-AlEt3 (Fig. SM1), which unambiguously indicates that all signals observed for NEt3-AlEt3 at the ratio NEt3/AlEt3=1/1 are attributable to one compound. In Fig. SM1, the number (1) shows the signal corresponding to the cross-peak between the Al-ethyl fragments and nitrogen atom, while the cross-peak (2) relates to the interaction of methyl groups at nitrogen atoms and methylene groups at the aluminum atom. It is worthwhile to note that for the systems NEt3–AlEt3 (NEt3/AlEt3 ratio is higher or lower than 1), the NMR spectra shows either an excess of NEt3 (if NEt3/AlEt3 > 1) or an excess of AlEt3 (if NEt3/AlEt3 < 1), the ratio of the integrated signal intensities from free NEt3 or AlEt3 and NEt3→AlEt3 being correlated with the molar ratio of the components (see Fig. SM2 and Fig. SM3). After the reaction of Ni(acac)2 with AlEt3 (AlEt3/Ni(acac)2 = 5), the reaction solution contained no unreacted Ni(acac)2 (1H NMR) (Fig. 7 ). New signals at 0.06 (q, CH2), 1.21 (t, CH3), 1.51 (s, CH3) ppm are assigned to AlEt2(acac), the signal at 0.81 (s) ppm is attributed to ethane, and the signal at 3.44 (q) ppm corresponds to the Al–O–CH2 fragment of an alumoxano like compound. The signals at 0.26 (q, CH2) and 1.08 (t, CH3) ppm belong to the starting AlEt3. 13C NMR data (Fig. 8 ) also confirm the formation of AlEt2(acac). The signal at 59 (s) ppm is attributed to the Al–O–CH2–alumoxano-like fragment, and that at 18 (s) ppm is assigned an impurity present in the initial AlEt3. The 1H NMR spectrum of the system Ni(acac)2 – 5AlEt3 – 5NEt3 (Fig. 9 ) contains the signals of the starting unreacted AlEt3 (0.26 (q, CH2), 1.02 (t, CH3)), NEt3→AlEt3 adduct (0.11 (q, CH2), 0.75 (t, CH3), 1.39 (t, CH3), 2.28 (q, CH2)), AlEt2(acac) (1.22 (t, CH3)) and free triethylamine (0.98 (t, CH3), 2.41 (q, CH2)). The signal at 0.85 (s) ppm corresponds to ethane. The signal at 3.44 (q) ppm is assigned to Al–O–CH2– fragment of the alumoxano like compound. The 13C NMR spectrum of the system Ni(acac)2 – 5AlEt3 – 5NEt3 system (see Fig. 10 ) also shows the signals of an excess AlEt3 (8.87 (s, CH3)), unreacted triethylamine (12.37 (s, CH3), 46.73 (s, CH2)), and the adduct NEt3→AlEt3 (1.81 (m, CH2, CH3), 8.87 (s, CH3), 10.75 (s, CH3), 47.34 (s, СН2)). The broaden multiplet at 1.81 ppm (m, CH2, CH3) is probably due to the superposition of signals from AlEt3, NEt3, and NEt3→AlEt3. The appearance of a signal at 58.98 (s) ppm is explained by the formation of trace amounts of aluminoxane-like compounds in the system. Analysis of the 2D NOESY NMR spectrum (Fig. SM4) also confirms the above signal assignment. Moreover, a dynamic equilibrium is observed between the resulting adduct and the unreacted amine (Fig. SM4). In the 27Al NMR spectrum of the system Ni(acac)2 – 5AlEt3 – 5NEt3 (Fig. 11 ), two signals are recorded in the regions of 171 and 153 ppm, which correspond to NEt3→AlEt3 and AlEt3, which are in a dynamic equilibrium (see above). The signal at 9.94 ppm is assigned to the Al–O–CH2– fragment of an alumoxano-like compound. In the 1H-15N 2D HMBC NMR spectrum, two signals at −136 and −133 ppm are attributable to the adduct NEt3→AlEt3 and pure NEt3, respectively (see Fig. 12 ). The NMR data confirms the earlier assumption that the reaction of AlEt3 with NEt3 in a solution of toluene (or benzene) affords the NEt3→AlEt3 adduct both with and without nickel-containing sites. Since this adduct can be considered as frustrated Lewis pair (FLP) [56–60] and, hence, can promote the activation of the hydrogen molecule, a series of additional experiments on styrene hydrogenation has been conducted in the presence of only NEt3→AlEt3 under the same conditions as for Ni(acac)2 – nAlEt3 – mNEt3 (n = 5, m = 5). It is shown that with NEt3→AlEt3 in a narrow range of conditions, the styrene hydrogenation does not occur, the hydrogenation products being not detected even after 6 h at Т = 30°С and РH2 = 2 atm. Moreover, according to NMR data, in the course of styrene hydrogenation with NEt3→AlEt3 as well as in the presence of Ni(acac)2 – nAlEt3 – mNEt3 (n = 5, m/n = 0.125–2.0), no new signals appear in the spectrum, but intensity of the signals assigned to the Al–O–CH2 fragment increases. This is due to the reaction between trace water, which is contained in the reaction system and is located on the walls of the vessel, and AlEt3. In addition, during one experiment (2–20 h), no noticeable broadening of the signals has been recorded that indirectly evidences the absence of ferromagnetic centers in the system. Conclusions The data presented in this work are fully consistent with the previously formulated concept for the synthesis of multicomponent catalysts based on M(acac)2–Red (M=Ni, Co, Pd; Red=AlEt3, LiAlH4) [11,18]. Shortly, to initiate the catalytic activity of systems derived from M(acac)2–Red (M=Ni, Co, Pd; Red=AlEt3, LiAlH4), the modifiers are required. Depending on the nature of the modifier, nanosized metal-containing particles (proton-donor compounds, e.g., alcohols, water, organic acids are used as modifiers) [11,18] or metal-containing centers of subnanometer size, i.e. less than 0.7 nm in size (aliphatic or aromatic amines are used as modifiers), catalytically active in the hydrogenation of unsaturated compounds, will be formed in these systems. The nature of the modifier also affects the performance of the studied systems. It should come as no surprise that systems formed in the presence of subnanometer amines turned out to be much more productive than those produced with nan-sized proton-donor compounds. Meanwhile, the maximum activities of the considered systems are close. For example, TOF of the system Ni(acac)2 – 5AlEt3 – 15n-BuOH is approximately 75–80 min−1, while TOF of the Ni(acac)2 – 5AlEt3 – 2.5N(n-BuOH)3 is 83.8 min−1. Probably, these values depend on the experimental procedures (see Experimental part) and are limited to the achievable mixing speed in the reaction vessel. The model for the formation of a catalytically active site in the presence of an amine (for example, triethylamine) can be represented as follows: The excess AlEt3, which can be coordinated to the surface of the nickel-containing site due to donor-acceptor interaction, as well as through the production of surface compounds of the at-complex type, [Ni-Et]−AlEt2 +, and/or via the formation of polycenter bonds between the surface atoms of Ni and AlEt3 [11], acts not only as a stabilizer, but also as a catalytic poison. The formation of the NEt3→AlEt3 adduct leads to the appearance of catalytic activity, and since the aggregation of nickel-containing sites (generation of nanosized particles) is not observed during the hydrogenation, the stabilizing activity of NEt3→AlEt3 is comparable to that of the initial AlEt3. To further expand the applicability of the concept for the synthesis of multicomponent hydrogenation catalysts, the modifying ability of optically active proton-donor compounds or amines will be studied. This can open up new horizons for design of multicomponent catalytic systems with tailor-made enantioselectivity. In addition, the application of such proton-donor compounds as polysaccharides, permits to generate in situ 3D conformationally rigid, multipoint-linked, optically active polymer matrices with catalytically active sites as well as to create multicomponent regenerated hybrid nanobiocomposites. coredata.dc:description: The paper reports on a possible modification of the multicomponent catalytic system based on Ni(acac)2 and AlEt3 by different amines. It is shown that, depending on the nature of the amine, the performance of the modified Ni(acac)2–AlEt3 system is limited only to the size of the reaction vessel. Using various physical-chemical methods, it is found that during the formation of a catalytically active system, the NR3→AlEt3 adducts are produced. The latter, unlike AlEt3 excess, are not able of poisoning the nickel-containing catalytically active centers. The model of the formation of a catalytically active site in the presence of an amine is proposed.
coredata.dc:title: A new method for activation of multicomponent nickel catalysts for alkenes hydrogenation
